[h1] A Toxic Relationship Called Dota 2 [/h1]

[h2] Free to play. Paid in emotions. [/h2]

[b] Dota 2 isn‚Äôt a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs an emotional rollercoaster I never asked to get on. [/b]
You load in full of hope and log out mentally exhausted, questioning your life choices after one single ranked match that somehow lasts longer than most relationships.

Yes, it‚Äôs beautiful ‚Äî the colours, the effects, the heroes ‚Äî all stunning while your team finds creative new ways to lose. And yet, like every bad romance, you always come back. It breaks you, makes it up with one good match, and then hurts you all over again.

Dota 2 is not entertainment.
It‚Äôs heartbreak‚Ä¶ with better graphics.

And yet, we still love you, Dota‚Ä¶

https://youtu.be/sElE_BfQ67s

Dota 2 is waiting for you.

Dota 2 isn‚Äôt a game.
It‚Äôs a crime scene I keep returning to, even though I know exactly how the blood will dry.

I hate it ‚Äî the chaos, the ego, the teammates auditioning for a documentary called How to Ruin a Lead in 30 Minutes. Every match feels like a slow dissection of my patience. And yet‚Ä¶ I queue again. Like a moth circling the same flame that‚Äôs already burned its wings clean off.

Dota punishes you with precision. It studies you. It waits. Then it gives you one perfect moment ‚Äî the clutch fight, the immaculate execution, the hit of dopamine sharp enough to make you forget all the misery that came before it.
That‚Äôs the trick.
That‚Äôs how the darkness keeps you.

I don‚Äôt play because I love it.
I play because somewhere between the frustration and the thrill, I found a part of myself that refuses to let go.

So here‚Äôs my review:
Dota 2 is a game I despise‚Ä¶ and somehow, the only one I keep coming back to.

A toxic ritual.
A beautiful disaster.
My favorite mistake.

I‚Äôve played Dota ‚Üí HOTS ‚Üí LoL ‚Üí Dota again.
From experience, Dota‚Äôs strategic depth is far ahead of its competitors. Itemization, hero design, and core mechanics all have a much greater impact on how each game plays out.

If you prefer micro over macro play, Dota still holds up. It focuses less on pure skill shots and more on positioning, timing, and decision-making. With its many active items and abilities, you often manage anywhere from 2 to 13 buttons, sometimes even controlling multiple units with their own skills.

LoL feels faster and more reaction-based. You die quicker, and crowd control is usually shorter and easier to dodge. In Dota, disables tend to last longer, which shifts the focus toward planning and positioning rather than constant reflexes.

After returning to Dota, I can‚Äôt go back to LoL. Dota‚Äôs hero and item design are more engaging, and fights feel more deliberate‚Äîyou don‚Äôt just evaporate instantly.

Bonus points to Dota for its launcher and cosmetics‚Äîyou can customize music, merge skins, and the client works flawlessly. I once saw a streamer in a match pause, open demo mode to test an interaction, and resume the game within seconds. It‚Äôs simply more polished.
Mine master shall vouchsafe unto me the mantle of discipleship, an I prove worthy in the learning of this mystick craft.

Dota 2 remains one of the most complex, rewarding, and enduring games in the MOBA genre ‚Äî and for many, that depth is exactly its greatest strength. If you‚Äôre willing to invest time to learn and grow, Dota 2 offers unmatched variety, strategic richness, and social/competitive dynamics. On the other hand, the learning curve and time commitment mean it‚Äôs not ideal for casual or casual‚Äëtime players.

Dota 2 is a deep, complex, and highly competitive MOBA that rewards strategy, teamwork, and skill like no other game in the genre. With over a hundred unique heroes ‚Äî each with distinct abilities, playstyles, and roles ‚Äî the game offers endless replayability and a level of depth that continues to evolve over time.

The gameplay is intense and tactical, requiring players to think critically, communicate effectively, and adapt to ever-changing situations. Every match feels different, and the sense of progression, mastery, and constant learning keeps players coming back year after year.

Visually, the game remains polished and vibrant, and Valve‚Äôs ongoing updates ‚Äî from balance patches to seasonal events ‚Äî ensure the experience stays fresh and exciting. The esports scene further elevates the game, showcasing some of the most thrilling and skillful competitions in gaming.

‚≠ê Dota 2 ‚Äì A Brutal Masterpiece

Dota 2 isn‚Äôt just a game, it‚Äôs a long-term commitment. With deep mechanics, a constantly shifting meta, and over a hundred unique heroes, every match feels different and demands real strategy and skill.

üéÆ Gameplay

Fast, punishing, and incredibly rewarding. A single decision can change the whole match. It‚Äôs not just about mechanics; it‚Äôs about map awareness, timing, and teamwork, even though the ‚Äúteamwork‚Äù part doesn‚Äôt always go as planned.

üî• Pros

Huge hero roster with diverse playstyles

Consistent updates and evolving meta

Smooth graphics and animations

One of the biggest esports scenes

Extremely satisfying once you understand the depth

üò© Cons

Steep learning curve for new players

Matches can be long (40‚Äì60 minutes)

Community can be toxic

Major patches sometimes break your favorite hero

‚öñÔ∏è Final Verdict

Dota 2 is chaotic, challenging, and addictively fun. It‚Äôs a game that punishes mistakes but rewards mastery like no other. If you love competitive games that constantly push you to improve, this one is a masterpiece.

Score: 9/10 ‚Äî pain, joy, and perfection in one place.

Dota 2 ‚Äì Steam Review

Dota 2 is honestly a great and very addictive game. Every match feels different ‚Äî new heroes, new strategies, new team dynamics. One good fight can completely turn the game around, and that‚Äôs exactly what keeps me playing. Nothing is guaranteed until the very end.

The game feels super satisfying when things finally start to work out. Teamwork actually matters, and winning a tough match with good coordination feels amazing. That‚Äôs one of the best parts of Dota 2.

It can be challenging and sometimes frustrating, but that‚Äôs also what makes it exciting. It has its chaos, it has its intensity, but it also has a unique vibe that‚Äôs hard to find in other games. I keep coming back to it simply because it‚Äôs fun and it pulls you in more than you expect.

I definitely recommend it ‚Äî just be ready, because this game can hook you fast.

I lost my job, my parents disowned me, my wife left me, the community calls me a cretin, I lost all my hopes and dreams and local neighborhood kids make scary stories about my house. This game is literal crack cocaine. You say to yourself "It'll be just 1 hour." Then after a game you got stomped in you jump back in again and again in ranked match cue in archon rank spamming Ogre Magi's laugh voiceline every time your carry threatens to feed, with 9 other people who don't know a single word in the English vocabulary and after all that you look and see 5 hours have passed on the clock.

Gabe Newell and Ice Frog are sipping champagne on one of 100's of gold plated yachts they own laughing at the rat race they have created so that they can eternally torment and shatter the minds of sane hard working people. I am already long gone but to the person reading this, you still have a chance. For your sake please, don't  play support role Techies and spam bombs in the enemies secret shop or spam pick Meepo while having zero idea how he works in ranked matches.

‚≠ê Nostalgic Game Review: A Faithful Companion from College Days

There are some games that don‚Äôt just bring fun‚Äîthey hold pieces of our lives within them. This game is one of those‚Äîa loyal companion during late-night study sessions, a comfort between deadlines, and the reason our friends gathered in the dorm or classroom.

What makes Dota 2 special is the balance between complex gameplay and rich hero design. The game demands strategy, adaptability, and coordination, while the heroes bring personality and depth through their stories, abilities, and visual style. It feels more like a living battlefield than just a regular MOBA.

üéÆ Game Review: 7/10
PLEASE IMPROVE YOUR RANKING SYSTEM FOR THE LOVE OF THE PLAYERS

üîá Muted Communication is Killing Teamwork
This is a massive problem. If you try to talk strategy or make a complex call, the system instantly flags it as "communication abuse" and mutes you. The chat is too restricted. It makes every single match feel like a solo queue bot game with zero real communication. This destroys the entire idea of a strategic team game. You can't coordinate when the game punishes you for trying to talk.

üèÜ The Rank Grind is Unbearable
The ranking (MMR) system is flat-out unfair and way too slow compared to every other MOBA.

The issue is getting stuck with people who share your rank medal but are clearly much worse. Other games let you climb fast and leave the bad players behind. Dota 2 locks you in. You have to win a huge number of games just to move up one Division but in the same rank. That's 750 MMR across five divisions. It forces experienced players to constantly carry low-skill teammates, making the whole rank climb feel like an endless, exhausting treadmill.

‚ú® The Good Stuff
Cosmetics are top-tier. They look incredible and are worth the money. I appreciate that you can still get some quality items for free or with in-game currency.

Optimization is perfect. You can genuinely play this game well, even on a weak, old laptop. It runs smooth.

‚öîÔ∏è Gameplay: Genius Idea, Broken Balance
The core game is brilliant and easy to learn if you put in the time. The best part is how skills can be mixed and used in creative ways that no other game offers.

But is it balanced? Absolutely not.

The game has heroes that can abuse their skills because the drawbacks are too small. They have low mana costs and short cooldowns. They just spam abilities nonstop.

The whole game right now favors the "Clicker Meta." It's not about making smart, strategic plays anymore. It's about how fast you can click and execute actions. The game is basically rewarding high speed over smart decision-making, which is a letdown for a game this deep.

This game is the perfect simulator of the total collapse of everything you own. In the first 10 minutes of the match, you will understand who your true parent really is (spoiler alert: these will be all your teammates), and your mom will start her own tour of the genealogy of all the players on the server.

Every game is a new surprise! Either your kerry decides that his vocation is just to stand by the fountain, or the enemy team will so carefully tell you what exactly you are doing wrong in life.

I recommend it for masochists, linguists (learn countless new ways to combine swear words and genealogy) and those who have long dreamed of having their lives controlled by an invisible algorithm that captures your every mistake.

In general, the game is a real fire! It's just a blazing bonfire that burns your nerve cells.

negative.review: Do not touch this game. Be happy. Enjoy life, nature, family, and friends. Go to a bar, ride a bike, go hiking, do anything else. This game will ruin your life and your relationships, and you will end up alone, anxious, and traumatized.

Excellent game that is ruined by no moderation of its player base. Almost every game is toxic and players are allowed to ruin games with no consequences. (for the most part)
Would play it until I can move my hands and fingers but it brings more negativity into my life than positives.
Would be so easy to fix.

The game punishes new players. The lower your behavior score drops, the worse the people you are matched with. Anytime other players report you, even if its just for being inexperienced, you lose behavior points. The lower behavior points the other players have, the more they like to report. Its a never ending cycle where new players are stuck. I am new to games like this, and while I have begun to enjoy Dota for the gameplay, I am not the best at it. Even with over 100 hours I am still not the most talented player. The game makes you start out playing with random players of all ranks and skillsets so you are often matched with and against people who know more than you. Some are helpful and understanding, most are incredibly testy. They get angry over small mistakes, cuss, and rally others to start a reporting parade. If Dota changes their social credit system so it actually punishes people who are trolling, insulting, and abusing the game instead of punishing learning curves and the infrequent spotty internet error, I would recommend this game to most people.

I gave that game 140+ hours of pure passion and progress, and Valve repaid me with totalitarian speech controls, cooldowns & forced game modes. Fuc them, permanently uninstalled this trash.

Dota is the single greatest video game of all time in my opinion but Valve has ruined it by refusing to update the game in any meaningful way. The only updates we get are AI slop updates that give minor tweaks to heroes like +5 move speed -1 armor or cosmetic slop patches like the most recent one. These patches are essentially humiliation rituals for Dota lifers. Valve is clearly more interested in making more shitty failure games like Artifact instead of allocating more resources into improving an already proven game and e-sport. League of legends has like 180 heroes and Dota only has about 120. Imagine if Valve never wasted any resources on total failure Artifact and dogshit Deadlock and just made more heroes and more frequent more interesting balance patches how great Dota could have become.

What's the actual point of the behavior score system when I have 12k for both scores, and somehow every game, ranked or unranked, is still plagued by either a troll, a smurf, a new player, or is just one sided as all hell in some other aspect?
Evenly matchmade games, let alone games that just play out evenly, are so few and far between that even a victory just feels like time wasted, because what is there to learn from having a smurf on your team and getting carried? 
The crossover event with Monster Hunter sucks, too. Symbolic of how little Valve seemingly cares for this game at this point, considering how MH is doing as a game. 
The game has the potential to not suck, but unfortunately, the matchmaking consistently ruins the experience for both seasoned and new players.

EDIT: Reporting is broken. I can see when a report is successful, and I've had dozens of successful reports when it comes to griefing, afks, toxicity, but not a single time have I ever seen any of the painfully obvious smurfs (0 games steamrolling with Invoker or Meepo, stupid crap like that), ever get a penalty. They always seem to get away from the report system. Wonder why that is. Almost like Valve has some interest in there being an influx of "new player accounts" and doesn't care whether they're really new players. In which case, they should remove the "smurfing" option in the report menu, because clearly it's not against the rules in their eyes.

This game would be cool if it applied a good MMR algorithm for its casual 'turbo' mode. A TON of the community plays this mode because of its speed and quality of life mechanics. Let's just put it this way - less people want to sweat in normal modes (where there's no concede option - so if you're blatantly losing in normal, have fun sitting around for 40min - 1hr+ for the game to end before you're allowed to move to the next. This means enjoy just slowly getting your ass kicked for 40min - 1hr+). Because there's no MMR mechanic in Turbo, it's a complete roll of the dice on player match up. You'll go against 5 pro's while your team has 1 or 2 new players. The devs put a cool little message - "Be kind to new players" - because to them, even though most of the community plays this mode, it's the training grounds. The issue - is in the training grounds "be kind to new players" - pro's play it. Pro's play it.... because they don't want to play 1hr long normal games. So it creates a toxic experience. So you're either faced with playing a shitty turbo with random MMR game (typically games are not even matched - this happens less of the time than more of the time. By evenly matched I mean either one side or the other just rolls the other team because the algo is so bad at line up. And very occasionally gets it right where the game feels like a good back and forth), or suffer in normals with a much slower pace and much harder mechanics. This game would be cool if 1) It had a good MMR algo for turbo (like introduce ranking in turbo for god sakes lazy ass devs) and 2) They allowed conceding. Since they don't - I can't recommend this game after about 2,300 matches played. 75% turbo. Normals are just... not an option. I can't sit there (like the majority of the community) for 1hr+ at a time and ESPECIALLY when you're getting your ass kicked with no concede and you just have to let the game play out until the enemy team can end it. Absolutely doggy dog dog this game is. Lazy dev force with like 3 people running the show at this point. Cannot recommend.

After 8,803 hours in DotA 2, I‚Äôm convinced this game is the purest form of emotional Stockholm Syndrome. It‚Äôs a masterpiece and a mistake, a love story and a toxic relationship, and yet every day I still find myself clicking Play like an addict convincing myself ‚Äújust one game‚Äù ‚Äî knowing full well it‚Äôll ruin my night.

Pros

+ The highest highs you will ever feel gaming
Pulling off a game-winning Black Hole, landing a 5-man Ravage, or timing that perfect Echo Slam ‚Äî the dopamine is illegal. When a coordinated team play comes together, you ascend spiritually.

+ Infinite skill ceiling
8,803 hours in and I still learn something new. A new ward spot, a new timing, a new way to throw the game. This thing is a never-ending education in pain and improvement. Only DotA lets you feel both genius and clown in the same match.

+ The hero diversity and depth is absurd
Every patch feels like learning a new game. 125+ heroes, item reworks, map changes ‚Äî you can‚Äôt ever fully master it. And that‚Äôs the beauty. DotA is alive, unpredictable, chaotic, and brilliant.

+ Teamplay that (sometimes) feels like symphony
A coordinated 5-man smoke gank is art. A well-timed Save? Poetry. When strangers understand each other without speaking ‚Äî that‚Äôs intimacy.

Cons

‚Äì Very easy to waste your life ‚Äî I would know
8,803 hours. That‚Äôs 366 continuous days. I could‚Äôve learned a language. I could‚Äôve built a house. Instead I warded highgrounds and argued with strangers about support items.

‚Äì Teamwork is a myth most days
For every beautiful game, there are fifty where your mid buys Midas into a losing lane and your carry farms jungle minute 48. Matchmaking is where hope goes to die.

‚Äì Tilt is not a feeling ‚Äî it‚Äôs a lifestyle
You can win five in a row, feel like God, then one stomped match will destroy your entire sense of identity. This game doesn‚Äôt just defeat you ‚Äî it humiliates you.

‚Äì The patch cycle makes you question your sanity
Learn everything, feel finally confident ‚Äî boom, new patch. The map grows a new cave, Roshan moves to another universe, and suddenly your favourite hero feels like a wet sock.

Final Verdict

DotA 2 is the best terrible game ever made.
It gives you euphoria and existential crisis at the same time.
I hate it. I love it.
I hate that I love it, and love that I hate it.

And tomorrow, I‚Äôll queue another match.
Because nothing else hits quite like DotA.

9/10 ‚Äî would suffer again.

I feel like the game has become trash over the years. I remember a time when people actually played in their own ranked. Lobbies were fairly balanced. But now, it feels like you‚Äôre just wasting your time. Good lobbies are rare, people troll the game, smurf accounts, try new heroes in ranked, or copy random builds from YouTube. What I mean is nobody seems to care about winning anymore. 
This is a complex game. It requires brainpower, thinking, and focus. It‚Äôs like chess. Over the years, the old players who respected the game left, and new players came in and ruined it by treating it like a simple game. It‚Äôs not a simple game.If you want something easy, go play Mario. 

Anyway, I loved this game, and I know I‚Äôm not the only one. There were so many people who truly enjoyed it, but for me, Dota has been dead for a long time. Yet I still keep playing it, and I honestly don‚Äôt know why. If you‚Äôre a new player or thinking about starting, please respect the game and your teammates. After all, it‚Äôs a team game, if you ruin a match, you ruin it for four other people at the same time. Learn the game, think strategically, and if all you want is a casual game, PLEASE never install this game.

Dota 2 is the best game I‚Äôve ever played in my life. And I‚Äôm not saying that lightly since I‚Äôve got around 15k‚Äì20k hours in this game. The concept, the constant updates, the pro scene, the custom games‚Ä¶ everything about Dota is incredible. But there‚Äôs one thing that matters more than all of that.
Matchmaking.
And unfortunately, Dota 2‚Äôs matchmaking system is so bad that you‚Äôll consistently find yourself leaving games tilted, frustrated, or downright confused. It‚Äôs the one flaw that overshadows everything else this masterpiece has to offer. 
So when asked. Would you recommend this game to others? My answer is No. Do not play this game. The it has been 6 years since my last review and no change.

If you are worried about your mental health, I gotta warn ya, dota 2 community is toxic as HELL and Valve made it super easy for these toxic people to report you "for no reason at all".. yeah that's right. each player gets to report another, 6 times in each match. and it does not end at this point. admins who ban ya also dont know anything about roles. For example if pick a sup and the carry is too dumb to make the game a win, you CAN NOT act like a boss and stand up for kills. You gotta just move behind the dumbest core ever till enemy finishes the game in 60 mins. That is what this game has transformed to. A pool of toxicity that when you show creativity, they just throw you to LOW priority. NOW, what is low priority you may ask? Its a match unlike what you installed on your computer. in fact you kinda get to play another game. with only 3 heroes. its a game of chances that this toxic community LOOOOOVEEEES. I've been playing since dota 1. so more than your age probably. I recommend that you don't install this game until they fix the Behavior Score policy. it just ruins your day when you are super niceee and super creative and then coming back to your PC to play a game in which you payed $2000 of skins, and NOPE you can not play this game. you gotta play Single draft with the most stupid players on the surface of this planet till you win 5 matches. and you wont win for like 10 or 12 matches which takes 5 days of a normal human with a JOB ^_^ yeahh. Also the ranking system is super stupid. you just cant win a 1 v 9 game when you get the worst team mates who think of nothing but ruining your experience and revenge on "why did you tell me to buy wards?". as Gaben said, he does not care about our feedback. He just does what he wants to.

This game genuinely changed my life for the worse. The moment i opened this game my mother was hit by a truck tire flying at 200km/h after a brutal accident. After she died, it turned out that she misspelled my name in the will and everything she left me was sent to a random person. After that, I sat down and tried to play the game, but my chair broke and i fell onto the floor. In anger, i threw my broken chair at a wall, which made my entire house collapse. Because my house collapsed, all my possessions were buried under the rubble and the only thing that remained was my PC setup. I tried to calm down by playing some Dark Souls III, but my steam library glitched and now the only game I can play is Overwatch 2. While I was playing, I got a phone call saying that I had been convicted for murder and was going to prison for life, because when I collapsed my house, the shock wave caused my neighbours cooking oil to tip onto his turned on gas stove, which blew him up immediately. When I got to prison, they said I was being sentenced to death, and asked for my last meal. I wanted a Big Mac no pickles, but McDonalds got the order wrong and gave me a cold McChicken with extra pickles. Don't trust the price tag on this game, it seems cheap but the cost is really much higher than the actual price tag. This game has ruined my life.

Dota 2 is an amazing game, that is better then the fucking league in every way i like. The reason because this review is negative is because this game pretty much fucked up my life. Is it majorly because of my irresponsibility? Sure. But no game other than this is nearly as addictive once you get into it. It was a dark period of me living in my 14m¬≤ playing this game for up to 16 hours per day, with this game giving me illusion of accomplishment with each win, and a need to get my MMR back whenever I lose. A neverending cycle of dopamine rush and withdrawal. Stopping playing it was the best decision of my life. If you ever realise that you are spending too much time in this game - uninstall it and promise to yourlelf that you will never play it again, even when the friends are asking you. If you are responsible or already have an established life thay you are reasonably happy with - this game probably won't hurt you, and it may be good for you. But if you are an irresponsible student with ADHD like me - don't ever even think about getting into this. Because if you like it, you might end up like me.

Dota is a completely broken game. For the last few weeks, the Dota servers disconnect from me, I get an error message that says "No longer communicating with game servers," then I am the one who gets penalized (I have to wait 3 minutes before I'm allowed to queue again, as if I disconnected from the lobby).

In addition, Dota's ranking/matchmaking is completely broken. I am constantly placed in all Spanish-speaking or Russian or Chinese-speaking lobbies, despite only queueing up for North American servers. Then these guys all report me because I can't understand their languages. So MY behavior/communication score gets worse.

And, last, I am a new player with not too many hours in the game, but I constantly play against VERY GOOD players whose accounts are only one or two days old. They are called "smurfs" and they are ruining my games. But in the end, I'm the one who gets reported by them and their parties.

What a total joke from a "Steam-developed" game. There is no development going on, not really. The behavior system is totally broken.

Dota 2 is an incredibly deep and exciting game with endless strategic possibilities. The gameplay, hero variety, and constant updates make every match feel unique and rewarding. I‚Äôve enjoyed many great moments, and the competitive environment keeps the experience intense and engaging.
However, one major issue that holds the game back is the smurfing problem. It affects match quality and can make games feel unfair, especially for newer or lower-ranked players. I really hope the developers take stronger action to balance and reduce smurfs in the game.
Overall, Dota 2 is a fantastic experience, but with better handling of smurf accounts, it could be even more enjoyable for everyone.
